abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is rated
            highly satisfactory, and sustainability is likely. Several
            lessons are drawn from the project: 1) Political agendas may
            hinder the operation of state-owned commercial banks, since
            publicly appointed Boards of Directors may advocate
            increased services, without regards to the growth of
            profits, maximized by the Government's implicit
            guarantee of deposits in state-owned banks. 2) Nonetheless,
            the Government's commitment to, and ownership of the
            reform program becomes paramount to successful reforms,
            championed by both local, or external technical expertise,
            through appropriately planned public relations programs to
            attract the population's support. 3) The strategy to be
            followed in the privatization of state-owned banks, requires
            long-term, and resources to build consensus among key
            decision-makers and the public at large, and, likewise,
            capacity building in the Central Bank, is a long-term
            exercise in the achievement of the financial system
            supervision. 4) Both the Government, and the Central Bank
            should be in full agreement on the final output from
            management contracts for distressed state-owned banks, and
            this includes the willingness to enforce compliance with
            business plans targets, and effective oversight of the
            performance of the management contractor. Technical
            expertise is suggested for banks performance evaluation.

18155187.theme: Other financial and private sector development,State-owned enterprise restructuring and privatization,Regulation and competition policy

abstracts.cdata!:
The Government of Tanzania wishes to
            implement a strategy which would address the fundamental
            weaknesses in the financial sector while building the
            foundation for the diversification of financial instruments.
            The main elements of this strategy are: 1) encouraging
            competition in the commercial banking sector; 2)
            strengthening banking regulation and supervision; 3)
            improving the payments mechanism especially in rural areas;
            4) promoting and supporting comprehensive parastatal
            reforms, including privatization, of state owned
            enterprises; 5) developing a market for Government
            securities; 6) establishing a regulatory structure for
            securities and insurance markets; and 7) developing a
            corporate securities market. In this context, the primary
            objectives of the Financial Institutions Development Project
            are to develop a market oriented financial system and to
            ensure the orderly and gradual evolution of capital markets.
            The project will include the following components: 1)
            restructuring and privatization of National Bank of Commerce
            and People's Bank of Zanzibar within an agreed
            timetable; 2) strengthening of Bank of Tanzania's
            Supervision Directorate; 3) developing a mechanism for
            regulating the insurance industry; 4) studies on possible
            improvements to the payments system and the feasibility of a
            private credit information bureau; and 5) technical
            assistance to develop an appropriate mechanism for
            regulating and overseeing the evolution of a capital market.
